Package org.apache.juneau.commons.collections

Class FilteredMap<K,V>

java.lang.Object
java.util.AbstractMap<K,V>
org.apache.juneau.commons.collections.FilteredMap<K,V>
Type Parameters:
K - The key type.
V - The value type.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Map<K,V>
public class FilteredMap<K,V> extends AbstractMap<K,V>
A map wrapper that filters entries based on a BiPredicate when they are added.

This class wraps an underlying map and applies a filter to determine whether entries should be added. Only entries that pass the filter (i.e., the predicate returns true) are actually stored in the underlying map.

Features:
  • Flexible Filtering: Use any BiPredicate to filter entries based on key, value, or both
  • Optional Filter: Filter is optional when using the builder - defaults to accepting all entries
  • Multiple Filters: Can combine multiple filters using AND logic
  • Custom Map Types: Works with any map implementation via the builder's inner method
  • Type Conversion: Supports automatic type conversion via key/value functions
  • Convenience Methods: Provides add(Object, Object), addAll(Map), addAny(Object...), and addPairs(Object...) for easy entry addition
  • Transparent Interface: Implements the full Map interface, so it can be used anywhere a map is expected
  • Filter on Add: Filtering happens when entries are added via put(Object, Object), putAll(Map), etc.
Usage:

// Create a filtered map that only accepts non-null values FilteredMap<String, String> map = FilteredMap .create(String.class, String.class) .filter((k, v) -> v != null) .build(); map.put("key1", "value1"); // Added map.put("key2", null); // Filtered out map.put("key3", "value3"); // Added // map now contains: {"key1"="value1", "key3"="value3"}

Example - Custom Map Type:

// Create a filtered TreeMap that only accepts positive values FilteredMap<String, Integer> map = FilteredMap .create(String.class, Integer.class) .filter((k, v) -> v != null && v > 0) .inner(new TreeMap<>()) .build(); map.put("a", 5); // Added map.put("b", -1); // Filtered out map.put("c", 10); // Added

Behavior Notes:
  • Filtering is applied to all entry addition methods: put(Object, Object), putAll(Map), etc.
  • If the filter returns false, the entry is silently ignored (not added)
  • When put(Object, Object) filters out an entry, it returns the previous value associated with the key (if any), or null if the key did not exist. This allows callers to distinguish between a new entry being filtered out versus an existing entry being filtered out.
  • The filter is not applied when reading from the map (e.g., get(Object), containsKey(Object))
  • All other map operations behave as expected on the underlying map
  • The underlying map type is determined by the inner method (defaults to LinkedHashMap)
Thread Safety:

This class is not thread-safe unless the underlying map is thread-safe. If thread safety is required, use a thread-safe map type (e.g., ConcurrentHashMap) via the inner method.

See Also:

    • FilteredMap

      protected FilteredMap(BiPredicate<K,V> filter, Map<K,V> map, Class<K> keyType, Class<V> valueType, Function<Object,K> keyFunction, Function<Object,V> valueFunction)
      Constructor.
      Parameters:
      filter - The filter predicate. Can be null (if null, all entries are accepted).
      map - The underlying map. Must not be null.
      keyType - The key type. Must not be null (use Object.class to disable type checking).
      valueType - The value type. Must not be null (use Object.class to disable type checking).
      keyFunction - The key conversion function, or null if not specified.
      valueFunction - The value conversion function, or null if not specified.

      Returns:

    • create

      public static <K, V> FilteredMap.Builder<K,V> create()
      Creates a new builder for constructing a filtered map with generic types.

      This is a convenience method that creates a builder without requiring explicit type class parameters. The generic types must be explicitly specified using the diamond operator syntax.

      When using this method, type checking is effectively disabled (using Object.class as the type), allowing any key and value types to be added. However, the generic type parameters should still be specified for type safety.

      Example:

      // Explicitly specify generic types using diamond operator var map = FilteredMap .<String, String>create() .filter((k, v) -> v != null) .build();

      Type Parameters:
      K - The key type.
      V - The value type.
      Returns:
      A new builder.

    • put

      public V put(K key, V value)
      Associates the specified value with the specified key in this map, if the entry passes the filter.

      If the entry passes the filter, it is added to the map and this method returns the previous value associated with the key (or null if there was no mapping).

      If the entry is filtered out, it is not added to the map. This method returns the previous value associated with the key (or null if there was no mapping). This allows callers to distinguish between a new entry being filtered out versus an existing entry being filtered out.

      Specified by:
      put in interface Map<K,V>
      Overrides:
      put in class AbstractMap<K,V>
      Parameters:
      key - The key with which the specified value is to be associated.
      value - The value to be associated with the specified key.
      Returns:
      The previous value associated with key, or null if there was no mapping for key. This applies whether the entry was added or filtered out.

    • putAll

      public void putAll(Map<? extends K,? extends V> m)
      Specified by:
      putAll in interface Map<K,V>

    • wouldAccept

      public boolean wouldAccept(K key, V value)
      Tests whether the specified key-value pair would pass the filter and be added to this map.

      This method can be used to check if an entry would be accepted by the filter without actually adding it to the map. This is useful for validation, debugging, or pre-checking entries before attempting to add them.

      Example:

      FilteredMap<String, Integer> map = FilteredMap .create(String.class, Integer.class) .filter((k, v) -> v != null && v > 0) .build(); if (map.wouldAccept("key", 5)) { map.put("key", 5); // Will be added }

      Parameters:
      key - The key to test.
      value - The value to test.
      Returns:
      true if the entry would be added to the map, false if it would be filtered out.

    • getFilter

      public BiPredicate<K,V> getFilter()
      Returns the filter predicate used by this map.

      This method provides access to the filter for debugging, inspection, or advanced use cases. The returned predicate is the combined filter used internally by this map. If multiple filters were set via the builder, they are combined using AND logic.

      Example:

      FilteredMap<String, Integer> map = FilteredMap .create(String.class, Integer.class) .filter((k, v) -> v != null && v > 0) .build(); BiPredicate<String, Integer> filter = map.getFilter(); // Use filter for other purposes

      Returns:
      The filter predicate. Never null.

    • add

      public V add(Object key, Object value)
      Adds an entry to this map with automatic type conversion.

      This method converts the key and value using the configured key/value functions (if any) and validates the types (if key/value types were specified when creating the map). After conversion and validation, the entry is added using the standard put(Object, Object) method, which applies the filter.

      Type Conversion:
      • If a key function is configured, the key is converted by applying the function
      • If a value function is configured, the value is converted by applying the function
      • If no function is configured, the object is used as-is (but may be validated if types were specified)
      Type Validation:
      • If key type was specified (via create(Class, Class)), the converted key must be an instance of that type
      • If value type was specified (via create(Class, Class)), the converted value must be an instance of that type
      • If create() was used (no types specified), Object.class is used, which accepts any type
      Return Value:
      • If the entry is added successfully, returns the previous value associated with the key (or null if there was no mapping)
      • If the entry is filtered out, returns null (even if there was a previous value)
      Example:

      FilteredMap<String, Integer> map = FilteredMap .create(String.class, Integer.class) .filter((k, v) -> v != null && v > 0) .valueFunction(o -> Integer.parseInt(o.toString())) .build(); map.add("key", "123"); // Value converted from String to Integer

      Parameters:
      key - The key to add. Will be converted if a key function is configured.
      value - The value to add. Will be converted if a value function is configured.
      Returns:
      The previous value associated with the key if the entry was added, or null if there was no mapping or the entry was filtered out.
      Throws:
      RuntimeException - If conversion fails or type validation fails.

    • addAll

      public FilteredMap<K,V> addAll(Map<?,?> source)
      Adds all entries from the specified map with automatic type conversion.

      This method iterates over all entries in the source map and adds each one using add(Object, Object), which applies conversion and validation before adding.

      Example:

      FilteredMap<String, Integer> map = FilteredMap .create(String.class, Integer.class) .filter((k, v) -> v != null && v > 0) .valueFunction(o -> Integer.parseInt(o.toString())) .build(); Map<String, String> source = Map.of("a", "5", "b", "-1"); map.addAll(source); // Values converted, negative value filtered out

      Parameters:
      source - The map containing entries to add. Can be null (no-op).
      Returns:
      This object for method chaining.

    • addAny

      public FilteredMap<K,V> addAny(Object... values)
      Adds arbitrary values to this map.

      Objects can be any of the following:

      • Maps of key/value types convertible to the key/value types of this map.

      Each entry from the maps will be added using add(Object, Object), which applies conversion and filtering.

      Example:

      FilteredMap<String, Integer> map = FilteredMap .create(String.class, Integer.class) .filter((k, v) -> v != null && v > 0) .build(); Map<String, Integer> map1 = Map.of("a", 5, "b", -1); Map<String, Integer> map2 = Map.of("c", 10); map.addAny(map1, map2); // Adds a=5, c=10 (b=-1 filtered out)

      Parameters:
      values - The values to add. Can be null or contain null values (ignored).
      Returns:
      This object for method chaining.

    • addPairs

      public FilteredMap<K,V> addPairs(Object... pairs)
      Adds a list of key/value pairs to this map.

      The pairs are processed in order, with each pair consisting of two consecutive elements in the array. Each pair is added using add(Object, Object), which applies conversion and filtering.

      Example:

      FilteredMap<String, Integer> map = FilteredMap .create(String.class, Integer.class) .filter((k, v) -> v != null && v > 0) .build(); map.addPairs("a", 5, "b", -1, "c", 10); // Adds a=5, c=10 (b=-1 filtered out)

      Parameters:
      pairs - The pairs to add. Must have an even number of elements.
      Returns:
      This object for method chaining.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - If an odd number of parameters is provided.
